title: Copilot Chat file editing not working - code appears in chat but doesn't modify files
body:
**Issue Description:**
Copilot Chat can read file contents perfectly but cannot modify files when using filepath comments. When I ask Copilot to edit a file, it shows the code changes in the chat but the actual file remains unchanged.

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Open a file in VS Code (e.g., Header.tsx)
2. Ask Copilot Chat to modify the file
3. Copilot provides code with `// filepath:` comment
4. Code appears in chat but file is not actually modified
5. File shows no changes (no dot next to filename, content unchanged)

**Expected Behavior:**
Copilot Chat should directly modify the file when providing code with filepath comments, and the file should show as modified in VS Code.

**Actual Behavior:**
Code appears in chat only, no actual file modification occurs.

**Environment:**
- VS Code Version: [current version]
- Copilot Chat Extension Version: [current version]
- OS: Windows 11
- Workspace: Local project folder

**Additional Context:**
This functionality worked previously but stopped working recently. File reading works perfectly - only file writing/editing is broken.

title: : VS Code Agent loops on .NET 8 WPF app (runs after a long time but never reaches the requested result)
body:
Type: Bug Environment Windows [10/11] VS Code [version] VS Code Agent [version] .NET SDK 8.x Models tried: Claude Sonnet 4, ChatGPT, GrokFast Summary I ask the Agent to build a simple Windows desktop app that reads from an HTTP API. It picks .NET 8 + WPF + Material Design and starts coding. What actually happens: It gets stuck in a long error/fix loop. Sometimes the app eventually runs, but only after a long time, and it never achieves the requested functionality. During the loop it tries very basic or unrelated steps (tiny UI stubs, console mode, rewriting the whole project from scratch), then repeats. It often claims progress (or “ran the app”) and moves on to write docs even though the end result isn’t there. Expected A project that builds quickly, launches the main window, and implements the simple HTTP flow—or at least delivers a minimal, working version that matches the request. Actual Long cycles, partial runs, and no usable final result. The Agent keeps restarting or trying trivial changes instead of fixing the real issues. Steps to Reproduce New folder in VS Code (Windows). Ask: “Create a modern Windows desktop app that reads from an HTTP API. Pick the best tech and implement it.” Let the Agent scaffold, build, and run. Observe long loops; app may run, but the requested outcome never arrives. Impact Lots of time wasted; I can’t get a basic, working desktop app with the Agent, even on Microsoft’s own stack. Attachments (optional) Build/run logs Example project the Agent generated Request Please stop the loop where the Agent claims success without delivering the requested result. Ensure it reads real build/run output, fixes root causes, and produces a minimal but working WPF/.NET 8 app that meets the ask. title: Bad Relative Path Separator

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: workbench-tabs
labels.description: VS Code editor tab issues

labels.name: insiders-released
labels.description: Patch has been released in VS Code Insiders

body:
Hi everyone, I’ve configured a custom relative path separator (`explorer.copyRelativePathSeparator`) in VS Code settings. It works correctly when I copy a relative path from the Explorer or a normal file tab. However, when I copy a relative path from a tab that shows Git diffs of the same file (for example, when comparing changes in Source Control), the custom separator is ignored and VS Code uses the default one instead. So it seems the custom setting is not applied in diff views. Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: **Yes** - VS Code Version: Code 1.104.1 (0f0d87fa9e96c856c5212fc86db137ac0d783365, 2025-09-17T23:36:24.973Z) - OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 **Steps to Reproduce:** 1. In VS Code settings, configure a custom value for Relative Path Separator. 2. Open any file in the workspace. 3. Right-click the file tab or in the Explorer → choose Copy Relative Path → ✅ custom separator is applied. 4. Now, open the same file in a Git diff view (e.g. from Source Control or by comparing revisions). 5. Right-click the diff tab → choose Copy Relative Path. **Expected** The copied relative path should use the custom separator. `wp-content/maintenance.php` **Actual** The copied relative path ignores the custom separator and uses the default one. `wp-content\maintenance.php`

title: Chat participant followupProvider not rendering follow-up questions
body: - Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.31.1 - VS Code Version: 1.104.1 (0f0d87fa9e96c856c5212fc86db137ac0d783365, x64) - OS Version: Microsoft Windows 11 Enterprise (Build 26100) - Feature: Chat participant followupProvider functionality - Selected model: Any model (issue is with UI rendering, not model-specific) - Logs: No errors in console or output - provider function executes successfully but UI doesn't render follow-up questions ## Summary Chat participant followupProvider is not rendering follow-up buttons despite correct implementation following official samples. ## ## Steps to Reproduce 1. Clone the official Microsoft VS Code extension samples repository: ```bash git clone https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-extension-samples.git ``` 2. Navigate to the chat sample extension: ```bash cd vscode-extension-samples/chat-sample ``` 3. Install dependencies and build the extension: ```bash npm install ``` 4. Open the chat-sample folder in VS Code and press `F5` to run the extension in a new Extension Development Host window 5. In the Extension Development Host, open the Chat view (Ctrl+Alt+I or View → Chat) 6. Send a message or slash command to the `@cat` participant, the documentation uses `@cat /teach` but the current implementation provides `@cat /randomTeach` 7. Wait for the response to complete 8. **Expected:** Follow-up buttons should appear below the chat response (the cat sample implements `followupProvider` that should return follow-up options) 9. **Actual:** No follow-up buttons are rendered, despite the `followupProvider` being implemented in the sample code and expected to display in Chat Participant API [documentation and screenshots](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/extension-guides/ai/chat#4-register-follow-up-requests) **Additional verification:** - Check the Extension Development Host console for any errors (there should be none) - Verify the `followupProvider` function is being called by adding console.log statements to the sample - Confirm the provider returns valid `ChatFollowup[]` objects **Code reference in sample:** The cat sample at `vscode-extension-samples/chat-sample/src/extension.ts` implements `followupProvider` but the follow-up questions don't render in the chat interface.

title: Enable Seamless One-Time Payments for Indian Customers Impacted by RBI Regulations
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->

## Feature Overview
Enable a robust feature in VS Code's billing and payment system that supports seamless one-time payments for customers in India affected by the Reserve Bank of India's recurring payment regulations. This should provide a user-friendly experience for monthly and yearly subscribers whose recurring payments are declined due to local banking restrictions.

## Context
The RBI regulation paused recurring payments for Indian customers, impacting access to paid features and subscriptions. GitHub has temporarily enabled one-time payments. VS Code should adopt or integrate a similar mechanism to minimize user disruption and maintain access continuity.

## Solution Proposal
- Allow monthly users to make a one-time payment on their billing renewal date.
- Allow yearly users affected between Oct 2021–Feb 2022 to pay for the outstanding period.
- Integrate clear notifications and reminders in the UI when payment is due, with direct links to payment settings.
- Automatically lock paid features/services if payment is not received within 14 days of reminders, with guidance to unlock.
- Collaborate with payment gateway providers to restore recurring payments for India.

## Impacted Services
- VS Code subscriptions (Pro, Team, Enterprise)
- Marketplace and extension purchases
- Sponsors and funding transactions
- Actions, Registry, Codespaces consumption

## References
- [RBI's press release](https://www.rbi.org.in/Scripts/BS_PressReleaseDisplay.aspx?prid=51353)
- [GitHub Support](https://support.github.com/contact)

title: Fix: Disable window shadows on macOS Tahoe to prevent GPU performance issues
body:
## Summary

Fixes #267022
Fixes #267065

related: https://github.com/electron/electron/issues/48311

macOS Darwin 26 (Tahoe) has a WindowServer bug that causes (some?) windows with shadows to consume 80%+ GPU resources. This change disables VSCode window shadows specifically for Darwin 25.x to work around the performance regression.

## Changes

- Added version check in `defaultBrowserWindowOptions` to detect Darwin 25.x
- Set `options.hasShadow = false` only on affected macOS versions
- Applied fix centrally to ensure all VSCode windows are affected consistently

## Testing

- Tested on macOS Tahoe - GPU usage drops significantly - from constant 80% to normal 15%

## Notes

This is a temporary workaround until Apple fixes the underlying WindowServer bug in macOS Tahoe. The version check can be refined or removed once the OS-level issue is resolved.

title: feature request: more flexibility with send to remote agent
body: so I went back and forth with the agent a bit about some changes it needed to make, was happy with what it understood and had it begin implementing. After like 5/10 minutes, I wanted to work on something else but it hadn't finished the agentic edits so I was stuck. I like what it did so far and all the work it was doing so I wish there was some way I could choose to send it off to the remote agent mid-session to finish out the tasks and everything. Was thinking I could stop the request, the re-run it or ask it continue and send that to the remote agent but wasn't confident that would work. I think ideal scenario is when a long running chat/agent mode session is happening, including a button that is like "send to remote agent" where the user could select mid-run to send it off.

title: Reinstate pause button

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
The previous version of GitHub Copilot Chat had a pause button. It should not have been removed. The pause button would preserve context and allow the user to elaborate or provide essential information that the agent is missing. In comparison, the stop button results in lost context which is less than ideal. 

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.31.0
- VS Code Version: 1.104
- OS Version: Windows 11 Pro 24H2
- Feature: Agent
- Selected model: Claude Sonnet 4
- Logs: N/A This is a missing agent interaction function resulting in poor UX

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Send a prompt
2. Realize the agent failed to identify essential context
3. Unable to pause to update context because the pause button was removed.

Related issues:
[Pause button missing](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/267706)
[Pause button does not appear anymore](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/266657)
[No means to pause/stop Copilot's processing](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/267026)
[Missing play/pause chat button](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/267181)
[Rambling Agent](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/266526)

title: VS Code native crash on Mac with error 5
body:
Type: Bug Much like [this issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/143101) I'm frequently receiving a crash with "error 5", preceeded by heavy slowness. Unlike that issue, I've managed to find a pretty reliable repro for it. What appears to trigger the problem is that a process is writing/deleting a ton of files inside the directory that vscode is looking at for its workspace. I'm unsure if editing the files will do it, but create and delete does. My directory structure is several levels deep, so that may also be involved. For this particular crash dump, I ran the process to create the files and then used `rm -rf` to delete them while clicking around in Code. The directory with lots of changes showed a spinning circle for a while, the UI was very slow, and then it crashed. I haven't tried yet without extensions, but I'll do that in a bit next time I'm debugging that particular process, since I have quite a few. I'm assuming for now that it's not an extension, since the other person linked above had basically the same symptoms. title: feat(scm): detect worktree hierarchy from inside and outside primary worktree closes #259083 #267612 #259083
body:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->
## Prerequisites
This PR improves recently introduced git worktree support.
1. Worktree detection improvements.
Worktree hierarchy in the `repository` tab of the SCM view is shown only when the **primary worktree** is open  as described in #259083 and upstream issues.
2. `${activeRepositoryName}` `window.title` variable
Currently, it simply shows the folder name of the _open worktree_.
By showing the `primary` worktree folder name instead, we'll support other variations to customize window.title.
If someone wants to stick to open worktree folder name, they can simply use `${folderName}` variable.
The detailed use-case is described in #251596.

The reason I combined these changes in a single PR is that primary repository name derivation is tightly coupled with the way SCM detects worktrees.

## Setup
```bash
mkdir test-folder && cd test-folder
git init repo && cd repo
touch test.txt && git add . && git commit -m "init" # introduce first commit
git worktree add test-worktree-inside
git worktree add ../test-worktree-outside
```
### Scenario 1: Opening the primary worktree 
It shouldn't be any different. Hierarchy is shown within the SCM view + worktrees are detected.
### Scenario 2: Opening the `test-worktree-inside` worktree
Should have the same output as Scenario 1.
### Scenario 3: Opening the `test-worktree-outside`
Should have the same output as Scenario 1.

## Notes
I could decouple the changes and submit another PR if required.
Also, I don't see any unit tests for the SCM `model.ts`. Let me know if I should add test coverage.
Although this PR improves worktree detection, it still doesn't support hierarchy using worktrees with bare repositories as reported in #267606

title: Fix NODE_OPTIONS environment variable inheritance on Windows
body:
## Summary
Fixes NODE_OPTIONS environment variable inheritance in VS Code integrated terminal on Windows. Currently, NODE_OPTIONS settings like `--max-old-space-size` are ignored when running Node.js processes from VS Code's integrated terminal on Windows, while they work correctly in regular cmd/PowerShell terminals.

## Associated Issue
Fixes #231076

## Root Cause
The issue has two parts:
1. **Platform Inconsistency**: The NODE_OPTIONS restoration logic was limited to macOS only (`if (isMacintosh)` condition)
2. **Missing Windows Support**: The Windows launcher script (`code.cmd`) didn't preserve NODE_OPTIONS like the macOS launcher does

## Changes Made

### 1. Updated Windows Launcher Script (`resources/win32/bin/code.cmd`)
- Added preservation of `NODE_OPTIONS` and `NODE_REPL_EXTERNAL_MODULE` environment variables
- Follows the same pattern as the macOS launcher script
- Variables are saved as `VSCODE_NODE_OPTIONS` and `VSCODE_NODE_REPL_EXTERNAL_MODULE` before being cleared

### 2. Extended Terminal Environment Restoration (`src/vs/workbench/contrib/terminal/common/terminalEnvironment.ts`)
- Removed macOS-only condition for NODE_OPTIONS restoration
- Made the restoration logic work on all platforms (Windows, macOS, Linux)
- Maintains backward compatibility with existing macOS behaviour

## How to Test

### Prerequisites
1. Set NODE_OPTIONS environment variable:
   ```powershell
   # In PowerShell (as Administrator for system-wide)
   [Environment]::SetEnvironmentVariable("NODE_OPTIONS", "--max-old-space-size=16384", "User")

title: Auto-approve rules are too loose
body: It seems like "Always allow exact command line" allows a lot more than the exact command line. I noticed this just now: Clicking through to my config it contains: ```json "npm run build": { "approve": true, "matchCommandLine": true } ``` If I'm reading this correctly, copilot could do anything in the world after that && and it would automatically run. Possible solutions: strict line matching as an option (Always allow exact command line vs Always allow exact command vs Always allow command), or split commands by logical seperators like &&, and require that each part is approved before running. - Copilot Chat Extension Version: latest - VS Code Version: latest - OS Version: Win 11 latest - Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): Agent - Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): Any / GPT-5 Steps to Reproduce: 1. title: Advice on issue management about classifying GitHub Copilot Chat-related issues
body:
Type: Feature request?

Many of the repo's issues (e.g. #267648) are (probably) created from "Report an issue" in GitHub Copilot Chat's thumbs-down button, but not labeled as such.

I notice the `ext-chat-issue` label in the "Copilot Bug report" issue template, but VS Code's issue generator doesn't add this to issues originating from the thumbs-down button*, so now the issue reading experience is not good, because there are a lot of unclassified GitHub Copilot Chat-related issues.

So I suggest to changing VS Code to when
- the issue comes from the thumbs-down button, or
- the issue's extension is GitHub Copilot Chat in its Issue Reporter (I don't know for sure which judgement is better)

then
- use the "Copilot Bug report" issue template, which has the `ext-chat-issue` label
- or add the `ext-chat-issue` label with some other means
- or just reroute those issues to https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-release/issues

\* As of version 1.104.1

title: Fix build script for build VSCode in Nix
body:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->

* Allow build vscode from tarball without .git directory
* Allow build vscode in macOS's clang without gcc alias
* Add node-gyp as dependency for node-pty's [postinstall script](https://github.com/microsoft/node-pty/blob/24b53bbf573ed7ab35f8897aa8b690dbd9064fc9/scripts/post-install.js#L81)
* Add integrity field for @emmetio/css-parser in extensions/emmet/package-lock.json by change git+ssh to https tarball
* Add buildTime env for deterministic build
* Allows customize the command that replaces `npm install`

title: How can I make Copilot edit only the selected area, not the entire file, in inline mode?
body: It's really annoying how Copilot changes so much of my code, which it thinks "fixes" but is actually wrong. It's also too slow because it processes the entire file, not just the part I'm working on. I just want to edit the selected area, which should be simple, but Copilot's behavior is frustrating, reading and editing whole file.

title: Feature Request: API to Retrieve Context Memory Usage for Copilot Models (Active/Inactive)
body:
## Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
There is no way to retrieve context memory information (e.g., current/max tokens used or available) for models in GitHub Copilot in VS Code – neither for active chats nor for inactive models. This makes it difficult to monitor or optimize context usage, especially in larger projects.

Examples of desired functionality:
- For active chat: A VS Code command or API that returns current token usage (input/output).
- For inactive models: Query the max context window per model (e.g., via settings or extension API), e.g., 128k for GPT-4o.

Related issues (that this overlaps with):
- #8303: Context window limits for Gemini 2.5 Pro
- #5706: Support for larger context and better reporting
- #39885 (in github/docs): Document max context size per model

## Describe the solution you'd like
- Add a new VS Code command: `copilot.contextMemory.retrieve` that returns JSON with { model: "gpt-4o", maxTokens: 128000, currentUsage: { input: 5000, output: 2000 } } for active chats.
- For inactive models: Extend the `github.copilot.chat.models` setting with context info, or add a read-only API.
- Include it in the Extension API for custom extensions.

## Describe alternatives you've considered
- Manual monitoring via VS Code Profiler (Developer Tools) – not programmatic.
- Custom extension with prompt logging – unreliable and not official.
- External OpenAI API – bypasses Copilot and does not provide Copilot-specific limits.

## Additional context
This would help with debugging context loss in long chats and optimization for large codebases. Research shows community interest (e.g., Reddit r/GithubCopilot threads from 2024–2025).

title: glob patterns doesn't apply, only "**" works.
body: - Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.31.1 - VS Code Version: 1.1041.1 - OS Version: Win 11 - Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): agent - Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): gpt-5 - Logs: Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create an insutction file under .github/instruction 2. Make it applyTo "**" 3. See it applys 4. Change it to applyTo: "**/*.md" (or any other pattern) 5. Make sure you are targeting .md file, and see that it doesn't apply. Of course, I would have expect it to work if I'm targeting the right pattern. Looking through other issues I couldn't tell if it suppose to fixed already or there is still an issue with the resolutions. Mainly because the documention about custom-instructions specifically mention that glob filterting should work and Github Copilot supposed to support it as well as sugeted here: https://github.blog/changelog/2025-09-03-copilot-code-review-path-scoped-custom-instruction-file-support/ Please advise.
